column1: Dakar (English:  ; French: [dakaʁ]; Wolof: Ndakaaru) is the capital and largest city of Senegal. The city of Dakar proper has a population of 1
column4: whereas the population of the Dakar metropolitan area is estimated at 2.45 million.The area around Dakar was settled in the 15th century. The Portuguese established a presence on the island of Gorée off the coast of Cap-Vert and used it as a base for the Atlantic slave trade. France took over the island in 1677. Following the abolition of the slave trade and French annexation of the mainland area in the 19th century
column5: Dakar grew into a major regional port and a major city of the French colonial empire. In 1902
column6: Dakar replaced Saint-Louis as the capital of French West Africa. From 1959 to 1960
column7: Dakar was the capital of the short-lived Mali Federation. In 1960
column8: it became the capital of the Independent Republic of Senegal.

column1: == History ==
The Cap-Vert peninsula was settled no later than the 15th century
column2: by the Lebou people
column3: an aquacultural ethnic group related to the neighboring Wolof and Serer. The original villages—Ouakam
column4: Ngor
column5: Yoff and Hann—still constitute distinctively Lebou neighborhoods of the city today. In 1444
column6: the Portuguese reached the Bay of Dakar
column7: initially as slave-raiders. Peaceful contact was finally opened in 1456 by Diogo Gomes
column8: and the bay was subsequently referred to as the "Angra de Bezeguiche" (after the name of the local ruler).  The bay of "Bezeguiche" would go on to serve as a critical stop for the Portuguese India Armadas of the early 16th century
column9: where large fleets would routinely stop
column10: both on their outward and return journeys from India
column12: collect fresh water from the rivulets and wells along the Cap-Vert shore and trade for provisions with the local people for their remaining voyage. (It was famously during one of these stops
column14: where the Florentine navigator Amerigo Vespucci began to construct his "New World" hypothesis about America.)

column1: The Portuguese eventually founded a settlement on the island of Gorée (then known as the island of Bezeguiche or Palma)
column2: which by 1536 they began to use as a base for slave exportation. The mainland of Cap-Vert
column3: however
column4: was under control of the Jolof Empire
column5: as part of the western province of Cayor which seceded from Jolof in its own right in 1549. A new Lebou village
column6: called Ndakaaru
column7: was established directly across from Gorée in the 17th century to service the European trading factory with food and drinking water. Gorée was captured by the United Netherlands in 1588
column8: which gave it its present name (spelled Goeree
column9: after Goeree-Overflakkee in the Netherlands). The island was to switch hands between the Portuguese and Dutch several more times before falling to the English under Admiral Robert Holmes on January 23
column11: and finally to the French in 1677. Though under continuous French administration since
column13: descended from Dutch and French traders and African wives
column14: dominated the slave trade. The infamous "House of Slaves" was built at Gorée in 1776.

column2: the Lebou of Cape Verde revolted against Cayor rule. A new theocratic state
column3: subsequently called the "Lebou Republic" by the French
column4: was established under the leadership of the Diop
column5: a Muslim clerical family originally from Koki in Cayor. The capital of the republic was established at Ndakaaru. In 1857 the French established a military post at Ndakaaru (which they called "Dakar") and annexed the Lebou Republic
column6: though its institutions continued to function nominally. The Serigne (also spelled Sëriñ
column7: "Lord") of Ndakaaru is still recognized as the traditional political authority of the Lebou by the Senegalese State today.

column1: The slave trade was abolished by France in February 1794. However
column2: Napoleon reinstated it in May 1802
column3: then finally abolished it permanently in March 1815. Despite Napoleon's abolition
column4: a clandestine slave trade continued at Gorée until 1848
column5: when it was abolished throughout all French territories. To replace trade in slaves
column6: the French promoted peanut cultivation on the mainland. As the peanut trade boomed
column10: proved ineffectual as a port. Traders from Gorée decided to move to the mainland and a "factory" with warehouses was established in Rufisque in 1840.

column1: Large public expenditure for infrastructure was allocated by the colonial authorities to Dakar's development. The port facilities were improved with jetties
column2: a telegraph line was established along the coast to Saint-Louis and the Dakar-Saint-Louis railway was completed in 1885
column3: at which point the city became an important base for the conquest of the Western Sudan.

column1: Gorée
column2: including Dakar
column3: was recognised as a French commune in 1872. Dakar itself was split off from Gorée as a separate commune in 1887. The citizens of the city elected their own mayor and municipal council and helped send an elected representative to the National Assembly in Paris. Dakar replaced Saint-Louis as the capital of French West Africa in 1902. A second major railroad
column4: the Dakar-Niger built from 1906–1923
column5: linked Dakar to Bamako and consolidated the city's position at the head of France's West African empire. In 1929
column6: the commune of Gorée Island
column7: now with only a few hundred inhabitants

column1: Urbanization during the colonial period was marked by forms of racial and social segregation—often expressed in terms of health and hygiene—which continue to structure the city today. Following a plague epidemic in 1914
column2: the authorities forced most of the African population out of old neighborhoods
column3: or "Plateau"
column4: and into a new quarter
column5: called Médina
column6: separated from it by a "sanitary cordon". As first occupants of the land
column7: the Lebou inhabitants of the city successfully resisted this expropriation. They were supported by Blaise Diagne
column8: the first African to be elected Deputy to the National Assembly. Nonetheless
column9: the Plateau thereafter became an administrative
column11: and residential district increasingly reserved for Europeans and served as model for similar exclusionary administrative enclaves in French Africa's other colonial capitals (Bamako
column16: established by Seydina Mouhammadou Limamou Laye
column17: was thriving among the Lebou in Yoff and in a new village called Cambérène. Since independence
column18: urbanization has sprawled eastward past Pikine
column19: a commuter suburb whose population (2001 est. 1
column21: 000) is greater than that of Dakar proper
column23: creating a conurbation of almost 3 million (over a quarter of the national population).

column1: In its colonial heyday Dakar was one of the major cities of the French Empire
column2: comparable to Hanoi or Beirut. French trading firms established branch offices there and industrial investments (mills
column3: breweries
column4: refineries
column5: canneries) were attracted by its port and rail facilities. It was also strategically important to France
column6: which maintained an important naval base and coaling station in its harbor and which integrated it into its earliest air force and airmail circuits
column7: most notably with the legendary Mermoz airfield (no longer extant).

column2: Dakar became involved in the Second World War when General de Gaulle
column3: leader of the Free French Forces
column4: sought to make the city the base of his resistance operations. The object was to raise the Free French flag in West Africa
column5: to occupy Dakar and thus start to consolidate the French resistance of its colonies in Africa. The plan had British naval support when fighting alone against the Axis powers. However
column6: due to delays and the plan becoming known
column7: Dakar had already come under the influence of the German controlled will of the Vichy government. With the arrival of French naval forces under Vichy control and faced by stubborn defences onshore
column8: de Gaulle's proposals were resisted and the Battle of Dakar ensued off the coast lasting three days September 23–25
column10: between the Vichy defences and the attack of the Free French and British navy. The enterprise was abandoned after appreciable naval losses. Although the initiative on Dakar failed
column11: General de Gaulle was able to establish himself at Duala in the Cameroons which became the rallying point for the resistance of the Free French cause.In November 1944 West African conscripts of the French army mutinied against poor conditions at the Thiaroye camp
column12: on the outskirts of the city. The mutiny was seen as an indictment of the colonial system and constituted a watershed for the nationalist movement.

column1: Dakar was the capital of the short-lived Mali Federation from 1959 to 1960
column2: after which it became the capital of Senegal. The poet
column3: philosopher and first President of Senegal Léopold Sédar Senghor tried to transform Dakar into the "Sub-Saharan African Athens" (l’Athènes de l’Afrique subsaharienne)
column4: as his vision was for it.

column1: Dakar is a major financial center
column2: home to a dozen national and regional banks (including the BCEAO which manages the unified West African CFA currency)
column3: and to numerous international organizations
column4: NGOs and international research centers. Dakar has a large Lebanese community (concentrated in the import-export sector) that dates to the 1920s
column5: a community of Moroccan business people
column6: as well as Mauritanian
column8: and Guinean communities. The city is home to as many as 20
column9: 000 French expatriates. France still maintains an air force base at Yoff and the French fleet is serviced in Dakar's port.

column1: Beginning 1978 and until 2007
column2: Dakar was frequently the ending point of the Dakar Rally.

column1: == Geography ==
It is located on the Cap-Vert peninsula on the Atlantic coast and is the westernmost city on the African mainland.
=== Climate ===
The Dakarois climate is generally warm. Dakar has an ocean-influenced hot semi-arid climate (Köppen climate classification: BSh)
column2: with a short rainy season and a lengthy dry season. Dakar's rainy season lasts from July to October while the dry season covers the remaining eight months. The city sees approximately 495 mm (19.5 in) of precipitation per year.

column1: Dakar between December and May is usually pleasantly warm with daily temperatures around 24–27 °C (75–81 °F). Nights during this time of the year are comfortable
column2: some 17–20 °C (63–68 °F). However
column3: between May and November the city becomes decidedly warmer with daily highs reaching 29–31 °C (84–88 °F) and night lows a little bit above 23–24 °C (73–75 °F). Notwithstanding this hotter season Dakar's weather is far from being as hot as that of African cities inland
column4: such as Niamey and N'Djamena
column5: where temperatures hover above 36 °C (97 °F) for much of the year. Dakar is cooled year-round by sea breezes.

column1: == Administration ==
The city of Dakar is a commune (also sometimes known as commune de ville)
column2: one of the some 125 communes of Senegal. The commune of Dakar was created by the French colonial administration on June 17
column3: 1887 by detaching it from the commune of Gorée. The commune of Gorée
column4: created in 1872
column5: was itself one of the oldest Western-style municipalities in Africa (along with the municipalities of Algeria and South Africa).

column1: The commune of Dakar has been in continuous existence since 1887
column2: being preserved by the new state of Senegal after independence in 1960
column3: although its limits have varied considerably over time. The limits of the commune of Dakar have been unchanged since 1983. The commune of Dakar is ruled by a democratically elected municipal council (conseil municipal) serving five years
column4: and a mayor elected by the municipal council. There have been 20 mayors in Dakar since 1887. The first black mayor was Blaise Diagne
column5: mayor of Dakar from 1924 to 1934. The longest-serving mayor was Mamadou Diop
column6: mayor for 18 years between 1984 and 2002.

column1: The commune of Dakar is also a department
column2: one of the 45 departments of Senegal. This situation is quite similar to Paris
column3: which is both a commune and a department. However
column4: contrary to French departments
column5: departments in Senegal have no political power (no departmental assembly)
column6: and are merely local administrative structures of the central state
column7: in charge of carrying out some administrative services as well as controlling the activities of the communes within the department.

column1: The department of Dakar is divided into four arrondissements: Almadies
column2: Grand Dakar
column3: Parcelles Assainies (which literally means "drained lots"; this is the most populous arrondissement of Dakar)
column4: and Plateau/Gorée (downtown Dakar). These arrondissements are quite different from the arrondissements of Paris
column5: being merely local administrative structures of the central state
column6: like the Senegalese departments
column7: and are thus more comparable to French departmental arrondissements.

column1: In 1996 a massive reform of the administrative and political divisions of Senegal was voted by the Parliament of Senegal. The commune of Dakar
column2: whose population approached 1 million inhabitants
column3: was deemed too large and too populated to be properly managed by a central municipality
column4: and thus on August 30
column5: 1996 Dakar was divided into 19 communes d'arrondissement. These communes d'arrondissement were given extensive powers
column6: and are very much like regular communes. They have more powers than the arrondissements of Paris
column7: and are more akin to the London boroughs. The commune of Dakar was maintained above these 19 communes d'arrondissement
column8: and it coordinates the activities of the communes d'arrondissement
column9: much as Greater London coordinates the activities of the London boroughs. The 19 communes d'arrondissement belong to either of the four arrondissements of Dakar
column10: and the sous-préfet of each arrondissement is in charge of controlling the activities of the communes d'arrondissement in his arrondissement.

column4: is the historical heart of the city

column1: Dakar is one of the 14 régions of Senegal. The Dakar région encompasses the city of Dakar and all its suburbs along the Cape Verde Peninsula. Its territory is thus roughly the same as the territory of the metropolitan area of Dakar. Since the administrative reforms of 1996
column2: the régions of Senegal
column3: which until then were merely local administrative structures of the central state
column4: have been turned into full-fledged political units
column5: with democratically elected regional councils
column6: and regional presidents. They were given extensive powers
column9: or environmental protection issues at the regional level
column10: thus coordinating the actions of the communes below them.

column1: == Notable sites ==
The city of Dakar is a member of the Organization of World Heritage Cities
column2: and contains several landmarks. One of the most notable is Deux Mamelles
column3: twin hills located in Ouakam commune. The hills are the only high ground in the city
column4: providing views of the entire  area and sweeping views of the city. The first hill is topped with Mamelles Lighthouse built in 1864. The second hill has the newly completed African Renaissance Monument built on top
column5: which is considered the tallest statue in Africa.Other landmarks of the city include the medina quarter located in Médina commune. Médina is originally built as a township for local populace during the French colonial-era. Today it is a traditional commercial center packed with tailor's shops. The most notable street market is Soumbédioune
column6: which is also a major tourist attraction. The quarter also houses Dakar Grand Mosque at the heart of the commune
column7: which is built in 1964 and one of the prominent landmarks of the city.

column1: Dakar is flanked by two small islands
column2: Île de N'Gor and Île de Gorée. The former is on the northern shore of N'Gor commune with beaches providing attractions such as surfing. N'Gor commune also has other popular beach resorts such as Plage de N'Gor. Île de Gorée
column3: formerly a slave island
column4: is today a UNESCO World Heritage Site which preserves the colonial era architectures and facilities. The notable places on the island is Gorée Memorial which is a memorial for the slaves
column5: and the House of Slaves which is a museum dedicated to the Atlantic slave trade. Today
column6: the island is also hosting the art scene of the hundreds of local artists who line up their works at the outdoor exhibitions.Some other notable places include Layen Mausoleum which entombs the founder of the Layene Sufi tariqa
column7: Palais Présidentiel which is the seat of the government constructed in 1907
column8: Place de l'Indépendance which is the central square of Dakar
column10: and Cheikh Anta Diop University also known as the University of Dakar

column1: == Places of worship ==
Among the places of worship
column2: there are predominantly Muslim mosques.    There are also Christian churches and temples : Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Dakar (Catholic Church)
column3: Assemblies of God
column4: Universal Church of the Kingdom of God.

column1: Dakar was selected as the Capital of Islamic Culture for African Region for the year 2007 by the Islamic Educational
column2: Scientific and Cultural Organization (ISESCO)
column3: honoring its Islamic heritage. ISESCO and its parent organization Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) have held several regional and international conferences in the city
column4: best known for adoption of Dakar Declaration in 1991 which aimed at fostering the cooperation between the member states.  Dakar is also known as the birthplace of the Layene Brotherhood
column5: a Sufi tariqa founded by Seydina Mouhammadou Limamou Laye in 1883 at the commune of Yoff. Seydina is buried in the Layen Mausoleum which is among the major landmarks of Dakar. Today
column6: Layene Brotherhood is consisted mostly of the Lebou people
column7: and based in the Cap-Vert area. It is also the third biggest Sufi order in Senegal.

column1: Prominent worshiping sites for Muslims in Dakar include the Grand Mosque of Dakar
column2: built in 1964
column3: which is situated at Allée Pape Gueye Fall of Medina
column4: the Mosque of the Divinity
column5: constructed in 1973
column6: situated in Ouakam
column8: and Omarienne Mosque with minarets topped by green orbs.

column1: == Culture ==

In Senegal the traditional culture is very centred around the idea of family. This even includes the way that they eat. When it is time to eat a typical meal someone will say "kay lekk" which means 'come eat'. Everyone will come together and sit around the plate and eat with their hands. Some famous dishes include Cebbu Jën (Tiéboudienne) and Yassa. The etiquette of people in Dakar is very simple but very vital. To not greet someone upon sight is to portray rudeness and oftentimes ignorance. Due to French colonialism the children of Dakar have a unique school system. The school will get a break at about midday and return home to get some rest. Since the population is majority Muslim there are daily activities such as going to the mosque at noon prayer and attending the mosque on Fridays. Music has a big influence on the youth with famous artists like Daara J Family who use their voice to represent the problems in their communities.Dakar is home to multiple national and international festivals
column2: like World Festival of Black Arts
column3: Festival international du film de quartier de Dakar
column4: Dakar Biennale. It was also the location of Taf Taf
column5: an international artist residency program.

== Sports ==
Sports club AS Douanes are based in Sicap-Liberté; they play in the Senegal Premier League and previously won the 2014–15 Ligue 1 (Senegal) season.
Dakar used to be the finishing point of the Dakar Rally until 2007
column2: before the event was moved to South America for the security concerns in Mauritania.Dakar was set to host the 2022 Summer Youth Olympics however the games have been postponed to 2026
column3: it will be the first of its kind Olympics ever held in Africa.

column1: == Transport ==
The town is home to the Autonomous Port of Dakar and the terminus of the non-functioning Dakar-Niger railroad line.

The Train Express Regional (TER) will connect Dakar with Blaise Diagne International Airport (AIBD).  An initial 36 km will link Dakar to Diamniadio and a second phase of 19 km would connect Dakar to the Blaise Diagne airport. A total of 14 train stations will be served and the fastest end-to-end journey will take 45 minutes. The railway is expected to carry 115 000 passengers per day. The TER's first test run has been launched on 14th of January 2019 and the first passenger train is scheduled to run later this year.
